description:
Solanum virginianum, also known as the yellow-fruited nightshade or long-spined nightshade, is a species of plant belonging to the Solanaceae (nightshade) family. It is a perennial herb native to parts of Asia and Africa, including India, Pakistan, and parts of the Middle East.

The plant is characterized by its spiny stems and leaves, which are covered in sharp, yellow-colored spines. The leaves are deeply lobed and have a distinctive silvery-green appearance. The flowers are small, white, and star-shaped, and are typically followed by round, yellow-colored fruits that resemble small tomatoes.

Solanum virginianum is known to be a source of various secondary metabolites, including alkaloids and steroidal glycosides, which give the plant its characteristic pungent and bitter taste. These compounds have been the subject of scientific interest due to their potential medicinal properties, including anti-inflammatory, antimicrobial, and anti-cancer activities.

The plant is often found growing in disturbed habitats, such as roadsides, wastelands, and cultivated fields. It is considered an invasive species in some regions, where it can outcompete native plants and disrupt local ecosystems.
